text.Prompt:
The operator of the crippled Fukushima nuclear plant said it has removed a 20-ton piece of rubble from a destroyed reactor in what it called a "major step forward" in decommissioning.

After months of planning, Tokyo Electric Power Co (Tepco) said it used giant cranes on Sunday to lift one fuel handling machine, which was destroyed when a quake-sparked tsunami sent some of the plant's reactors into meltdown in March 2011.

The company described the delicate operation as a critical step toward clearing highly radioactive spent fuel rods from the cooling pool inside its badly damaged Reactor number 3.

The fuel handling machine was a key part of the process that transferred nuclear fuel assemblies into the reactor core.

"It paves the way for continued progress and is a milestone in reducing the risk of removing spent fuel assemblies," said the company's chief decommissioning officer Naohiro Masuda.

Removing fuel from the pool at the site's reactors is scheduled to last until the second half of 2021.

However, decommissioning efforts to clean up the debris at the shattered plant are expected to last some four decades.

The announcement comes several days after the government said compensation costs from the worst nuclear disaster since Chernobyl in 1986 are expected to be more than $57 billion.

Tokyo has poured billions of dollars into the embattled company to keep it afloat as it stumps up cash for decommissioning the reactors, cleaning up the mess from the disaster and paying compensation.

Generate a summary:
text.Response A: Tokyo Electric Power Company (Tepco) has completed a "major step forward" in decommissioning the Fukushima nuclear plant, removing a 20-ton piece of rubble from Reactor 3. The debris was a fuel handling machine, which was destroyed in March 2011 when a tsunami sparked a meltdown at the plant. This was the first time the company has used cranes to remove debris from the plant, and is considered a significant step towards clearing the highly radioactive spent fuel rods from the cooling pool. The process is expected to take until the second half of 2021, but the decommissioning process is expected to last some four decades. Tepco's Chief Decommissioning Officer Naohiro Masuda said: "It paves the way for continued progress and is a milestone in reducing the risk of removing spent fuel assemblies."
text.Response B: Tokyo Electric Power Co. said it has removed a 20-ton piece of rubble from a destroyed reactor at the Fukushima nuclear plant, a "major step forward" in decommissioning.

These include SBI Holdings' SBI Virtual Currencies, GMO Internet, Kabu.com Securities and Money Partners Group, Nikkei reports on Tuesday.

"We didn't even have minimum guidelines… so users will now feel more secure," a representative from SBI told the publication.

Japan is witnessing something of a Bitcoin renaissance in 2017. A giant uptick in trading quickly combined with a cementing of regulatory perspective see business deals come thick and fast.

Despite day-to-day Bitcoin use remaining low, plans in the pipeline for increasing acceptance alone suggest that underlying confidence in future spending habits is unwavering.

Since the shake-up of the Chinese exchange market in January, Japan now holds around 40 percent of Bitcoin trading volumes.

At the same time, news last week that its ten-year yields had declined to zero percent for the first time since 2007 stoked speculation investors may continue to seek alternatives in future.

As a result of the applications, ten new players are expected to debut on the market. Japanese companies like SBI Holdings, GMO Internet, Kabu.com Securities and Money Partners Group are among those applying for the new license. This boom in trading combined with a firm regulatory stance has cemented Japan's place as a major cryptocurrency player.

The country is believed to hold around 40% of the world's Bitcoin trading volumes, with over 18 companies having applied for a license to operate a cryptocurrency exchange in the country. Japan introduced the licensing scheme in April in a bid to ensure that exchanges operate in full compliance with financial regulation and anti-fraud procedures.

text.Prompt:
According to THEnergy, until very recently, there was little activity among mining companies regarding renewable energy. A recent report from CDP, formerly known as the Carbon Disclosure Project, concluded that the biggest miners are "unprepared for the transition to a low-carbon economy". 11 large mining companies were analysed and 9 opposed new climate regulations and only two stated support for "climate regulation." Perhaps this is due to the fact that for many mining companies, the main threat lies in new charges on coal.

Following this, THEnergy has realised that many of the large mining companies have started to focus on short-term actions regarding powering their mines: they have been preparing actions plans to react to carbon-reduction measures that might be adopted at the Paris climate conference. Large mining companies are also working on a strategy for renewable-energy projects such as wind and solar power at their mines. Companies like Rio Tinto, Glencore, BHP Billiton and Goldfields have already finished their first pilot power plants or have recently announced new projects.

Energy typically amounts to approximately 20–30% of the operating costs of a mine as such strict carbon-reduction decisions at the Paris climate conference could have a strong influence on the cost position of mines. As renewable energy can be less expensive than electricity from conventional energy sources, THEnergy stated, mining companies that manage to adapt early to the challenges of a low-carbon economy could gain significant competitive advantages.

"Mining companies are in the process of understanding that renewable energy can largely improve their competitive situation. Many miners struggle, however, to make the necessary decisions quickly as they face severe market challenges from falling commodity prices at the same time," explained Dr. Thomas Hillig, CEO of the consulting firm THEnergy, which specialises in the topic of renewables and mining. "We are in a normal learning process, many mining companies have already understood that the prices of solar and wind power have decreased considerably in the last years. If significant carbon reduction measures are adopted at the Paris climate conference, we will see many solar and wind plants at mines in the very near future."

Edited from press release by Angharad Lock

text.Response A:
Sure! Here is a summary of the article you provided:

Mining companies have been slow to adopt renewable energy sources, but recent advancements in technology and changing attitudes towards climate change have led to increased investment in renewable energy projects. This shift towards renewable energy is primarily driven by the potential for cost savings, as renewable energy can be less expensive than traditional energy sources. Large mining companies such as Rio Tinto, Glencore, BHP Billiton, and Goldfields have already implemented or announced new renewable energy projects. The use of renewable energy in mining operations can improve competitiveness and reduce operating costs, making it a key area of focus for companies looking to stay ahead in the industry.

text.Prompt:
A Chinese scientific research institute and value-added Internet service provider Tencent Holdings have jointly released a July 24 report emphasizing the impact of blockchain on the transformation of traditional financial services.

The Academy of Information and Communications Technology, a scientific research institute under China's Ministry of Industry and Information Technology (MIIT), and China's Tencent Holdings' report includes eight core conclusions of blockchain implementation in the financial sector.

According to the report, blockchain technology will further enhance the transparency of financial transactions, strengthen the flexibility of system operation, and automate processes, thus affecting the record keeping, accounting and payment settlement methods of financial services. The study further comments:

"In addition to digital currency, the characteristics of the blockchain can play a big role in the fields of payment and settlement, supply chain finance, securities trading, insurance, and credit reporting."

During the process of applying blockchain, the report notes, it is necessary to differentiate between the "coin" application and the "chain" application, presumably a reference to blockchain tech's basis for most cryptocurrencies:

"For the 'coin' application, the financial risk should be strictly guarded. For the 'chain' application, it should be legally regulated."

Earlier this week, three major Chinese telecom operators launched a blockchain research group for building a "next-generation telecommunication network." China will also lead an international research group on the standardization of the Internet of Things (IoT) and blockchain technology, as Cointelegraph reported July 18.

China has also recently downplayed blockchain tech, as the head of the international department of the China Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission warned against "mythologizing" blockchain technology in mid-July.

As China was the first country to institute blanket a ban on Initial Coin Offerings (ICO) and exchanges, Cointelegraph reports that the country has some difficulties with the decentralized and liberal freedoms that comes from blockchain and cryptocurrencies.

Generate a summary:
text.Response A: The Chinese Academy of Information and Communications Technology and Tencent Holdings have produced a report on the impact of blockchain on the transformation of traditional financial services, saying that blockchain technology will further enhance the transparency of financial transactions, strengthen the flexibility of system operation and automate processes. The report also suggests that the characteristics of the blockchain can play a big role in the fields of payment and settlement, supply chain finance, securities trading, insurance and credit reporting.
text.Response B: China's Academy of Information and Communications Technology has released a report in conjunction with value-added internet service provider Tencent Holdings. The report, entitled "Blockchain Technology and Financial Services", suggests that blockchain technology will increase the transparency of financial transactions, as well as strengthen the flexibility of system operation and automate processes. The report also suggests that blockchain technology can play a major role in payment and settlement, supply chain finance, securities trading, insurance and credit reporting. However, the report also states that the "coin" application of blockchain technology must be strictly guarded against financial risk, and that the "chain" application of blockchain technology must be legally regulated.

text.Prompt:
2016 has become an all-out war against cash. Last month, India almost instantly demonetized their most used paper currency notes, the 500 and 1000 Rs. This has caused massive problems throughout the country, resulting in the deaths of people as they wait in line to exchange money, and a soaring market for Bitcoin.

Now, embattled Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro announced on Sunday that the 100-bolivar bill will be decommissioned.

Haven't we heard this before?

In India, Prime Minister Narendra Damodardas Modi announced on Nov. 8 that the government would remove India's most used currency notes to fight "black money," or money that is undeclared and untaxed in the underground economy. On Sunday, President Maduro seems to have taken a page out of Modi's book, referring to "mafias" smuggling the currency.

President Nicolas Maduro said on state television:

"There has been a scam and smuggling of the one hundred bills on the border with Colombia. We have tried the diplomatic way to deal with this problem with Colombia's government; there are huge mafias. I have decided to take out of circulation bills of 100 bolivars in the next 72 hours. Sure! Here are the steps to clean a hot tub:

The judge described conditions for drivers as an "inhumane state of affairs'', and contrary to EU law...Ikea said it takes what drivers have told the BBC "very seriously'' and are "saddened by the testimonies". KUALA LUMPUR (May 4): Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd's (ANZ) chief hinted that 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB) concerns had an indirect impact on ANZ's stake in AMMB Holdings Bhd, The Australian reported today.

AMMB is also known as AmBank.

The Australian quoted ANZ chief executive Shayne Elliott as saying it was unquestionable that 1MDB' debt concerns and the Malaysian economy had a broad-base impact on Malaysian asset valuations. AMMB's share price was no exception, according to him.

"Has the 1MDB and the Malaysian economy and all those situations, impacted the AmBank share price? Unquestionably."

"It's impacted the valuation of lots of things in Malaysia, so it will have had an impact. But it's not a direct response to that," Elliott was quoted as saying in a press conference yesterday (May 3), during the announcement of ANZ's first-half financials.

ANZ via ANZ Funds Pty Ltd is the largest shareholder in AMMB, with a 23.78% stake.

At Bursa Malaysia today, AMMB shares rose eight sen or 1.8% at 12:30pm to RM4.56 for a market value of RM13.72 billion.

AMMB's current share price compares with the stock's one-year intraday high at RM6.21 seen on May 5, 2015.

In Australia yesterday, Elliott said there was "no 1MDB issue" for the ANZ board to discuss.

"We don't have an exposure to 1MDB. In terms of our partnership or the minority investment that we have in (AmBank's holding company) AMMB, all of those stakes get discussed regularly," he said.

Yesterday, ANZ said it incurred a A$260 million (about RM1.03 billion) impairment for its investment in AMMB during the first half ended March 31, 2016 (1HFY16).

ANZ told the Australian bourse that the AMMB impairment was among reasons for ANZ's weaker 1HFY16 financials, compared to a year earlier. During 1HFY16, ANZ said statutory profit after tax fell to A$2.74 billion, from A$3.51 billion.

At the press conference, Elliott said ANZ had cut its investment value in AMMB by almost 20% or A$260 million.

The Australian reported that "ANZ chief financial officer Graeme Hodges refused to say how much money AmBank had on loan to 1MDB."

Elliott also said that there was 'no 1MDB issue' for the ANZ board to discuss.  ANZ, via ANZ Funds Pty Ltd, is the largest shareholder in AmBank, with a 23.78% stake. text.Prompt:
Through a collaboration between the University of Edinburgh's Li-FI R&D Centre and a university offshoot company called pureLiFi Ltd, the past four years have brought light-powered Internet connectivity out of the theoretical stage and into a tangible Li-Fi router. The real-world applications for Li-Fi connectivity could revolutionize the way much of the world gets online. The R&D team bringing Li-Fi to the real world expects that solar homes, consumer gadgets, and Internet of things devices will all be able to absorb power and receive data simultaneously with a Li-Fi system in place.

The Li-Fi prototype relies on solar energy to power Internet connections so that an LED light source paired with a solar panel becomes a fully functional transmitter and receiver system for high speed, secure data transfer. Instead of relying on hardwired cables or radio waves that are easily interrupted, Li-Fi uses the nearly undetectable flicker of an LED light to transmit data.

Li-Fi is much faster than most standard Wi-Fi connections, and, perhaps most importantly, provides a connection that is significantly more secure. Because Li-Fi relies on light to transmit data, you have to be in the room with your device and the Li-Fi router in order to get connected. That would preclude strangers or literal outsiders from piggy-backing on your connection or eavesdropping on your online activity.

Beyond the widespread Internet access that Li-Fi could help provide around the world, the technology also has applications for reliable systems like smart city networks and Internet of Things connectivity in the smart homes of the future.

"The wider opportunity is to transform global communications by speeding up the process of bringing Internet and other data communication functionality to remote and poorer regions in a way not previously thought achievable due to lack of infrastructure and investment," said Tom Higgison, Edinburgh Research & Innovation's IP Project Manager. Edinburgh Research & Innovation is the commercial branch of the technological developments accomplished on the University side, and they have announced they are looking for industrial partners to help bring Li-Fi routers to a more mainstream audience.

Editors' Recommendations

This is done by using the nearly undetectable flicker of LED lights to transmit data. Li-Fi is more secure than standard WiFi connections because in order to connect to Li-Fi you need to be in the room with the light source. Li-Fi also has the potential to bring internet connectivity to remote and poorer regions in a way that was not thought to be achievable due to lack of infrastructure and investment.
text.Response B: A collaboration between Edinburgh's Li-Fi R&D Centre and a university offshoot company called pureLiFi Ltd has resulted in a Li-Fi router that can be used for high speed, secure data transfer.

text.Prompt:
A Chinese scientific research institute and value-added Internet service provider Tencent Holdings have jointly released a July 24 report emphasizing the impact of blockchain on the transformation of traditional financial services.

The Academy of Information and Communications Technology, a scientific research institute under China's Ministry of Industry and Information Technology (MIIT), and China's Tencent Holdings' report includes eight core conclusions of blockchain implementation in the financial sector.

According to the report, blockchain technology will further enhance the transparency of financial transactions, strengthen the flexibility of system operation, and automate processes, thus affecting the record keeping, accounting and payment settlement methods of financial services. The study further comments:

"In addition to digital currency, the characteristics of the blockchain can play a big role in the fields of payment and settlement, supply chain finance, securities trading, insurance, and credit reporting."

During the process of applying blockchain, the report notes, it is necessary to differentiate between the "coin" application and the "chain" application, presumably a reference to blockchain tech's basis for most cryptocurrencies:

"For the 'coin' application, the financial risk should be strictly guarded. For the 'chain' application, it should be legally regulated."

Earlier this week, three major Chinese telecom operators launched a blockchain research group for building a "next-generation telecommunication network." China will also lead an international research group on the standardization of the Internet of Things (IoT) and blockchain technology, as Cointelegraph reported July 18.

China has also recently downplayed blockchain tech, as the head of the international department of the China Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission warned against "mythologizing" blockchain technology in mid-July.

As China was the first country to institute blanket a ban on Initial Coin Offerings (ICO) and exchanges, Cointelegraph reports that the country has some difficulties with the decentralized and liberal freedoms that comes from blockchain and cryptocurrencies.

Generate a summary:
text.Response A:
The Academy of Information and Communications Technology and Tencent Holdings have released a report discussing the impact of blockchain technology on traditional financial services. The report highlights eight core conclusions for the implementation of blockchain in the financial sector, including enhanced transparency, automated processes, and improved record-keeping. The study emphasizes the importance of differentiating between "coin" and "chain" applications, with stricter financial risk management for the former and legal regulation for the latter.

China has been actively exploring the potential of blockchain technology, with three major telecom operators launching a research group for building a "next-generation telecommunication network" and China leading an international research group on the standardization of IoT and blockchain technology. However, the country has also expressed some reservations about the decentralized and liberal freedoms associated with blockchain and cryptocurrencies.

In conclusion, the report provides valuable insights into the potential of blockchain technology in the financial sector, while also acknowledging the need for careful risk management and legal regulation. China's ongoing exploration of blockchain technology highlights the country's commitment to harnessing innovation while maintaining regulatory oversight.
text.Response B:
Blockchain is a distributed ledger technology that is transforming the financial services industry by enhancing the transparency of financial transactions, strengthening the flexibility of system operation, and automating processes.  It is expected to have a significant impact on payment and settlement systems, supply chain finance, securities trading, insurance, and credit reporting.  It will enable new business models and use cases, and promote financial innovation.  However, the report emphasizes that it is necessary to differentiate between the "coin" application and the "chain" application of blockchain technology, and that financial risks should be strictly guarded.  

Overall, the report highlights the potential of blockchain technology to transform the financial services industry, and emphasizes the need for regulatory guidance and risk management.  It will be interesting to see how blockchain technology is adopted and regulated in China, and how it evolves globally in the financial services industry.

After months of planning, Tokyo Electric Power Co (Tepco) said it used giant cranes on Sunday to lift one fuel handling machine, which was destroyed when a quake-sparked tsunami sent some of the plant's reactors into meltdown in March 2011.

The company described the delicate operation as a critical step toward clearing highly radioactive spent fuel rods from the cooling pool inside its badly damaged Reactor number 3.

The fuel handling machine was a key part of the process that transferred nuclear fuel assemblies into the reactor core.

"It paves the way for continued progress and is a milestone in reducing the risk of removing spent fuel assemblies," said the company's chief decommissioning officer Naohiro Masuda.

Removing fuel from the pool at the site's reactors is scheduled to last until the second half of 2021.

However, decommissioning efforts to clean up the debris at the shattered plant are expected to last some four decades.

The announcement comes several days after the government said compensation costs from the worst nuclear disaster since Chernobyl in 1986 are expected to be more than $57 billion.

Tokyo has poured billions of dollars into the embattled company to keep it afloat as it stumps up cash for decommissioning the reactors, cleaning up the mess from the disaster and paying compensation.

The announcement comes several days after the government said compensation costs from the disaster are expected to be more than $57 billion.

The skies over America are set to get a lot noisier this holiday season with around a million new quadcopters expected to be unwrapped at the end of the year.

The prospect of so many untrained hobbyists send their remotely controlled machines skyward is causing some serious concern at the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA), which so far this year has had to deal with reports of hundreds of near misses between manned planes and drones.

With the technology gaining more exposure, and costs coming down, it's a dead cert the flying machines will be one of the most popular gifts this coming holiday season. And while the vast majority of people are sensible enough to consult their gray matter when it comes to working out the safest way – and place – to have fun with their copter, there's always a few bozos ready to spoil the party.

Voicing concern during the Airlines for America Commercial Aviation Industry Summit in DC this week, FAA official Rich Swayze said the agency was "trying to get out and educate people about potential dangers" of drones ahead of the holiday season, Aviation Week reported. "A lot of people who don't have a pilot background are operating these things in the airspace," Swayze said.

FAA action includes advising Walmart sales personnel on key safety points to pass on to consumers to ensure proper operation of the unmanned aerial vehicles. The retail giant currently offers dozens of drones or similar machines, some for as little as $20.

Also speaking at the conference, Hawaiian Airlines CEO Mark Dunkerley called quadcopters "a very serious issue," adding, "There's considerable concern that it's going to end in tears."

Know Before You Fly

Hoping to grab the attention of new hobbyist drone operators last Christmas, the FAA launched its "Know Before You Fly" video (above) on how to enjoy the machines without the worry of having it crash onto someone's head or, in a worst case scenario, bringing down a much bigger aircraft.

Safe operation includes keeping your flying machine below 400 feet and within sight at all times, and well away from airports and crowds. The FAA also recommends joining a flying club if there's one nearby, and to always inspect your aircraft before take-off. Happy flying!

Editors' Recommendations

text.Response A: There are a few steps you'll need to take in order to form an LLC in Illinois. First, you'll need to file Articles of Organization with the Illinois Secretary of State's office. You can find a copy of the form online. Once you've filed your Articles of Organization, you'll need to appoint a registered agent to receive legal documents on behalf of your LLC. Finally, you'll need to obtain an Employer Identification Number (EIN) from the IRS. This number is similar to a social security number for your business, and it will be used to file taxes and open bank accounts.

Sure, I can help you with that! Here are the general steps you'll need to take to form an LLC in Illinois:

1. Choose a business name: You'll need to choose a unique and distinguishable name for your LLC. You can search for existing businesses in Illinois to make sure your chosen name isn't already being used by another company.

2. Choose a registered agent: You'll need to appoint a registered agent to receive legal documents on behalf of your LLC. The registered agent can be an individual or a business, and they must be located in Illinois.

3. File the articles of organization: You'll need to file the articles of organization with the Illinois Secretary of State's office to officially form your LLC. This document will include information about your LLC, such as its name, registered agent, and purpose.

4. Obtain an employer identification number (EIN): You'll need to obtain an EIN from the IRS to identify your LLC for tax purposes. You can apply for an EIN online or by mail.

5. Register for taxes: You'll need to register your LLC for taxes with the Illinois Department of Revenue. This will typically involve filing an Illinois Business Tax Return (IBT).

6. Obtain licenses and permits: You may need to obtain additional licenses and permits depending on the type of business you're operating. For example, if you're a restaurant, you may need a food service permit.

7. Maintain records: You'll need to keep records of your LLC's activities, including financial records and minutes of meetings. These records will be helpful if you ever need to file taxes or deal with legal issues.

8. Provide information to the public: You'll need to provide information about your LLC to the public, such as its name, registered agent, and purpose. You can do this by filing a notice of organization with the Illinois Secretary of State's office.

I hope this helps! If you have any specific questions about forming an LLC in Illinois, feel free to ask me.

National Australia Bank's defence to similar claims of market manipulation and unconscionable conduct is due to be filed in October.

Unconscionable conduct

But the wording of parts of the NAB statement of claim, which was filed two months after the case against Westpac and three months after the case against ANZ, provided more scope for ASIC to make out its claim of unconscionable conduct, according to legal sources.

The filing of ASIC's newly drafted claims against Westpac and ANZ may coincide with the regulator launching a similar case against Commonwealth Bank of Australia, the only one of the big four banks not to have been sued over the allegations in the Federal Court.

ASIC refused to comment on the timing of any case against CBA. The bank is expecting a claim will be filed later this week.

It is understood CBA has no interest in settling with the regulator so long as it is required to provide an admission of unconscionable conduct. All of the banks are concerned such as admission will expose them to damages claims through class actions, after plaintiff law firm Maurice Blackburn said last month it is investigating such actions.

Advertisement

The Federal Court has set a provisional trial date for the cases of August 1 next year.

Tried together

In a case management hearing last month, Federal Court judge Jonathan Beach pushed back on ASIC's request for the case against ANZ to be heard first, which could have created a legal precedent to put pressure on the other banks to settle.

Rather, Justice Beach said his "provisional view" is that the three cases be tried together. He wants all the common issues vented at the first stage, and then to hear all the ANZ-specific issues, then the Westpac-specific issues and then the NAB-specific issues.

"I accept that in terms of the detail of some of the allegations and transactions there is still more to be disclosed by ASIC and to be looked at by each of the three banks, but it seems to be in relation to the matters of principle that I think all parties should have a fairly reasonable idea of what those issues of principle are at the moment," the judge said.

Another case management hearing is due to be held on August 22.

text.Prompt: Can you tell me how to clean a hot tub?
text.Response A:
Certainly! To clean a hot tub, you will need to follow a few steps to ensure that it is properly sanitized and safe to use.

First, you will need to drain the hot tub completely and remove any debris that may have accumulated in the water. This can be done by using a skimmer to remove any large objects, and then using a filter to remove any smaller particles.

Next, you will need to clean the inside of the hot tub. This can be done by using a mild soap and water solution to scrub down the walls and floor of the hot tub. Be sure to pay special attention to any areas that may have become particularly dirty, such as the jets or the filter.

Once the inside of the hot tub has been thoroughly cleaned, you will need to refill it with fresh water. Be sure to use a filter to remove any debris that may have entered the water during the refilling process.

Finally, you will need to add a sanitizer to the water to kill any remaining bacteria or other contaminants. This can be done by using a product such as chlorine or bromine, or by using a natural alternative such as hydrogen peroxide or baking soda.

It is important to note that the specific steps for cleaning a hot tub may vary depending on the model and manufacturer. Be sure to consult the owner's manual for your specific hot tub for detailed instructions on how to properly clean it.
text.Response B: Yes, cleaning a hot tub is very important to keep the water clean and safe for use.  The first step is to skim the surface of the water with a net to remove any leaves, dirt, or other debris.  Next, add a hot tub cleaning solution to the water and let it sit for several minutes.  Then use a long-handled brush to scrub the sides and bottom of the tub, and a pool skimmer to remove any debris from the water.  Finally, rinse the tub with a hose to remove all cleaning solution, and replace the water with fresh, clean water.

text.Prompt: Can you tell me how to make asian style fish cakes?
text.Response A:
Sure! Here's a simple recipe for making Asian style fish cakes:

Ingredients:
- 1 pound of fresh fish fillets
- 1/2 cup of finely chopped green onions
- 1/4 cup of chopped cilantro
- 1/4 cup of chopped red bell peppers
- 1/4 cup of cornstarch
- 2 large eggs
- 1 tablespoon of minced garlic
- 1 tablespoon of minced ginger
- 1 teaspoon of soy sauce
- 1 teaspoon of sesame oil
- Salt and pepper, to taste
- Vegetable oil, for frying

Instructions:
1. Cut the fish into small pieces and place in a food processor. Process the fish until it is minced and has a paste-like texture.
2. In a large bowl, combine the fish paste with the green onions, cilantro, red bell peppers, cornstarch, eggs, garlic, ginger, soy sauce, sesame oil, salt, and pepper. Mix well until the ingredients are thoroughly combined.
3. Heat the vegetable oil in a frying pan over medium heat.
4. Shape the fish mixture into small patties or cakes.
5. Fry the fish cakes in the hot oil until they are golden brown and cooked through, about 3-4 minutes per side.
6. Drain the fish cakes on a paper towel-lined plate to remove excess oil.
7. Serve hot or at room temperature with dipping sauces such as spicy mayo, sweet chili sauce, or soy sauce. Enjoy!

2016 has become an all-out war against cash. Last month, India almost instantly demonetized their most used paper currency notes, the 500 and 1000 Rs. This has caused massive problems throughout the country, resulting in the deaths of people as they wait in line to exchange money, and a soaring market for Bitcoin.

Now, embattled Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro announced on Sunday that the 100-bolivar bill will be decommissioned.

Haven't we heard this before?

In India, Prime Minister Narendra Damodardas Modi announced on Nov. 8 that the government would remove India's most used currency notes to fight "black money," or money that is undeclared and untaxed in the underground economy. On Sunday, President Maduro seems to have taken a page out of Modi's book, referring to "mafias" smuggling the currency.

President Nicolas Maduro said on state television:

"There has been a scam and smuggling of the one hundred bills on the border with Colombia. We have tried the diplomatic way to deal with this problem with Colombia's government; there are huge mafias. I have decided to take out of circulation bills of 100 bolivars in the next 72 hours. We must keep beating the mafias."

Venezuela is in the middle of a vicious case of hyper-inflation that has seen the rate for their bolivar versus the world's global reserve currency, and the U.S. dollar, fall over 50 percent in the black market within the past month. People wait in line for hours to shop for food or use ATMs. Paying a supermarket bill without a debit or credit card can often require a backpack full of cash. Many are asked to use bank transfers instead of cash or even card payments.

Bitcoin trading volume all-time high

Demand for Bitcoin has risen dramatically in Venezuela, as it has in India, with the amount of Bitcoin purchased on LocalBitcoins.com growing 1000 percent within the last six months, according to Coin Dance. With the bolivar losing so much value, it may be hard for Bitcoin to be purchased effectively in the region, as its price continues to move in the opposite direction.

Venezuela is on a growing list of nations with national currency devaluations. The list includes China, which has seen six national devaluations in the last twelve months, Zimbabwe, Brazil, Argentina, Spain, Italy, Great Britain and Ukraine. Every weakening of a nation currency, or a cash ban by a national banking system, seems to strengthen the global demand and value for Bitcoin.

Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro announced on Sunday that the 100-bolivar bill will be decommissioned. The move in Venezuela is likely to result in a similar demand for Bitcoin, as the currency continues to struggle with hyper-inflation and devaluation.

text.Prompt: Can you tell me how to tell if an employee is looking for a new job?
text.Response A:
It can be difficult to determine if an employee is looking for a new job without directly asking them. However, there are some signs that may indicate that an employee is considering a job change. Some of these signs include:

- Increased absenteeism: If an employee is regularly absent from work or late for work, it may be a sign that they are looking for a new job.
- Decreased productivity: If an employee's productivity decreases or they are no longer meeting deadlines, it may be a sign that they are not fully engaged in their work and are considering a job change.

Through a collaboration between the University of Edinburgh's Li-FI R&D Centre and a university offshoot company called pureLiFi Ltd, the past four years have brought light-powered Internet connectivity out of the theoretical stage and into a tangible Li-Fi router. The real-world applications for Li-Fi connectivity could revolutionize the way much of the world gets online. The R&D team bringing Li-Fi to the real world expects that solar homes, consumer gadgets, and Internet of things devices will all be able to absorb power and receive data simultaneously with a Li-Fi system in place.

The Li-Fi prototype relies on solar energy to power Internet connections so that an LED light source paired with a solar panel becomes a fully functional transmitter and receiver system for high speed, secure data transfer. Instead of relying on hardwired cables or radio waves that are easily interrupted, Li-Fi uses the nearly undetectable flicker of an LED light to transmit data.

Li-Fi is much faster than most standard Wi-Fi connections, and, perhaps most importantly, provides a connection that is significantly more secure. Because Li-Fi relies on light to transmit data, you have to be in the room with your device and the Li-Fi router in order to get connected. That would preclude strangers or literal outsiders from piggy-backing on your connection or eavesdropping on your online activity.

Beyond the widespread Internet access that Li-Fi could help provide around the world, the technology also has applications for reliable systems like smart city networks and Internet of Things connectivity in the smart homes of the future.

"The wider opportunity is to transform global communications by speeding up the process of bringing Internet and other data communication functionality to remote and poorer regions in a way not previously thought achievable due to lack of infrastructure and investment," said Tom Higgison, Edinburgh Research & Innovation's IP Project Manager. Edinburgh Research & Innovation is the commercial branch of the technological developments accomplished on the University side, and they have announced they are looking for industrial partners to help bring Li-Fi routers to a more mainstream audience.

KUALA LUMPUR (May 4): Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd's (ANZ) chief hinted that 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB) concerns had an indirect impact on ANZ's stake in AMMB Holdings Bhd, The Australian reported today.

AMMB is also known as AmBank.

The Australian quoted ANZ chief executive Shayne Elliott as saying it was unquestionable that 1MDB' debt concerns and the Malaysian economy had a broad-base impact on Malaysian asset valuations. AMMB's share price was no exception, according to him.

"Has the 1MDB and the Malaysian economy and all those situations, impacted the AmBank share price? Unquestionably."

"It's impacted the valuation of lots of things in Malaysia, so it will have had an impact. But it's not a direct response to that," Elliott was quoted as saying in a press conference yesterday (May 3), during the announcement of ANZ's first-half financials.

ANZ via ANZ Funds Pty Ltd is the largest shareholder in AMMB, with a 23.78% stake.

At Bursa Malaysia today, AMMB shares rose eight sen or 1.8% at 12:30pm to RM4.56 for a market value of RM13.72 billion.

AMMB's current share price compares with the stock's one-year intraday high at RM6.21 seen on May 5, 2015.

In Australia yesterday, Elliott said there was "no 1MDB issue" for the ANZ board to discuss.

"We don't have an exposure to 1MDB. In terms of our partnership or the minority investment that we have in (AmBank's holding company) AMMB, all of those stakes get discussed regularly," he said.

Yesterday, ANZ said it incurred a A$260 million (about RM1.03 billion) impairment for its investment in AMMB during the first half ended March 31, 2016 (1HFY16).

ANZ told the Australian bourse that the AMMB impairment was among reasons for ANZ's weaker 1HFY16 financials, compared to a year earlier. During 1HFY16, ANZ said statutory profit after tax fell to A$2.74 billion, from A$3.51 billion.

At the press conference, Elliott said ANZ had cut its investment value in AMMB by almost 20% or A$260 million.

The Australian reported that "ANZ chief financial officer Graeme Hodges refused to say how much money AmBank had on loan to 1MDB."

text.Response A: ANZ's CEO, Shayne Elliott, has revealed that concerns about 1MDB have had an indirect impact on ANZ's investment in AmBank, which owns a stake in AMMB Holdings. He said that the Malaysian economy had also been affected, although the bank doesn't have any direct exposure to 1MDB.

AmBank's share price was no exception. Elliott said that there was no 1MDB issue for the ANZ board to discuss as the bank did not have any exposure to 1MDB.

5. Bottles and sippy cups: If your baby is bottle-fed, bring a few empty bottles and a bottle brush to clean them. If your baby is old enough for sippy cups, bring a few to keep them hydrated.
6. Breast pump (if applicable): If you're breastfeeding, consider bringing a lightweight, portable breast pump to express milk on the go.
7. Pacifiers (if applicable): If your baby uses a pacifier, bring a few extra just in case they get lost or misplaced.
8. Snacks: Bring a few snacks that are easy to eat and won't make a mess, such as pureed fruits and vegetables, puffs, or teething crackers.
9. Toys: Bring a few toys that are safe for newborns, such as soft stuffed animals, rattles, or teething toys.

text.Prompt:
Dive Brief:

A group of students taught governors how to code at the annual National Governors Association meeting amid a national push to increase access to computer science courses.

EdTech: Focus on K-12 reports Code.org hosted the Hour of Code session, aiming to convince governors to require high schools to offer at least one computer science course, to fund teacher development to increase the number of qualified computer science teachers in their states, and to develop K-12 computer science standards.

Kentucky Gov. Matt Bevin has committed to getting computer science into every school, if only through online instruction at first, and Arkansas Gov. Asa Hutchinson said his state is well on its way to meeting Code.org's three goals after requiring high school coding classes and investing $5 million in teacher training.

Dive Insight:

Hour of Code events are one way to introduce students to coding and computer science more generally, but they are not nearly enough to prepare students for technology majors in college or for future jobs. A key criticism of the push to teach coding is that it doesn't provide students with computer science fundamentals that teach them the logic behind the skill. That's, ostensibly, what required high school courses could delve into.

Alternative post-secondary programs are having some of the same problems in finding a balance. Coding bootcamps have sprung up to provide adults with retraining opportunities that make them marketable to tech employers, but there is concern crash courses in programming languages that are popular now won't truly prepare people for the field. When new languages are created, computer scientists who know the logic behind them are better equipped to adapt. As high schools strive to prepare students for careers as well as college, this should be kept top of mind.

Generate a summary:
text.Response A: Coding is important to learn and understand because we are living in a world where everything is run by technology. We use it in our everyday lives, and we need to know how to use it.
text.Response B: A recent report from Code.org, the organisation that promotes computer science education, has highlighted that US state governors are increasingly being urged to increase access to coding courses. The report states that, as the popularity of coding grows, the demand for computer science professionals is expected to rise significantly in the next decade, and that, in order to meet this demand, the US government must ensure that all children have access to computer science education from an early age. This means that coding courses should be made mandatory in schools and that funding should be made available for teacher training to ensure that schools have the necessary staff to teach these courses. Furthermore, the report argues that the government should invest in the development of computer science standards to ensure that all children receive a high-quality education in this area.

After the launch of its product for Swiss investors, who expect a positive development in the price of Bitcoin to trade transparently on the SIX Swiss Exchange for the first time, Swiss bank Vontobel has extended its certificate on Bitcoin to Germany and Austria.

According to Heiko Geiger, its head of public distribution Europe, the tracker certificate offers investors a simple means of investing in the digital currency and the possibility to participate in the development of its price in USD, without having to own Bitcoins themselves.

He says to Cointelegraph:

"We see a huge interest in Bitcoin as an asset class. So, we have launched the product for the German/Austrian market, too. Germany is one of the biggest and most sophisticated structured products markets and it is one of Vontobel's focus markets."

The certificate is a simple bankable asset that is particularly suitable for investors who anticipate a rise in the acceptance and significance of Bitcoin as a way of payment and as an alternative currency.

Vontobel, which manages and monitors a client's assets entrusted to it and also observes the financial markets and interprets global macroeconomic developments, is the first Swiss issuer of a tracker certificate on Bitcoins for subscription.

Switzerland has been dubbed a conducive environment for Bitcoin to thrive, due to its regulatory friendly measures for the digital currency.

Good regulations

With the launch of this tracker certificate in Germany, Geiger says the environment could also be considered encouraging for similar investments.

"The fact that we have launched the product and are able to do a public offer shows that the regulatory environment in Germany also suits these kind of investments."

Before the launch in Switzerland, the bank maintained that the impact of the product on the price of Bitcoin "will most likely be very low." Trading commenced earlier this year on July 15, with Bitcoins purchased according to the subscriptions received from clients on that day, and with the products to be redeemed on July 23, 2018.

Depending on the market environment and the client interest, they will possibly issue a new product afterwards.

Vontobel's reputation spreads across 22 international locations where they identify and analyze trends, and subsequently create innovative investment strategies and products for investors.

Bots are tipped to completely change how we interact with companies — while we would have once used a company's app to interact with that company on our smartphone, bots are much easier and quicker to use. text.Prompt:
Through a collaboration between the University of Edinburgh's Li-FI R&D Centre and a university offshoot company called pureLiFi Ltd, the past four years have brought light-powered Internet connectivity out of the theoretical stage and into a tangible Li-Fi router. The real-world applications for Li-Fi connectivity could revolutionize the way much of the world gets online. The R&D team bringing Li-Fi to the real world expects that solar homes, consumer gadgets, and Internet of things devices will all be able to absorb power and receive data simultaneously with a Li-Fi system in place.

The Li-Fi prototype relies on solar energy to power Internet connections so that an LED light source paired with a solar panel becomes a fully functional transmitter and receiver system for high speed, secure data transfer. Instead of relying on hardwired cables or radio waves that are easily interrupted, Li-Fi uses the nearly undetectable flicker of an LED light to transmit data.

Li-Fi is much faster than most standard Wi-Fi connections, and, perhaps most importantly, provides a connection that is significantly more secure. Because Li-Fi relies on light to transmit data, you have to be in the room with your device and the Li-Fi router in order to get connected. That would preclude strangers or literal outsiders from piggy-backing on your connection or eavesdropping on your online activity.

Beyond the widespread Internet access that Li-Fi could help provide around the world, the technology also has applications for reliable systems like smart city networks and Internet of Things connectivity in the smart homes of the future.

"The wider opportunity is to transform global communications by speeding up the process of bringing Internet and other data communication functionality to remote and poorer regions in a way not previously thought achievable due to lack of infrastructure and investment," said Tom Higgison, Edinburgh Research & Innovation's IP Project Manager. Edinburgh Research & Innovation is the commercial branch of the technological developments accomplished on the University side, and they have announced they are looking for industrial partners to help bring Li-Fi routers to a more mainstream audience.

Editors' Recommendations

text.Response A: A collaboration between Edinburgh's Li-Fi R&D Centre and a university offshoot company called pureLiFi Ltd has resulted in a Li-Fi router that can be used for high speed, secure data transfer.

The technology uses solar energy to power internet connections, making it faster and more secure than traditional Wi-Fi. Li-Fi has applications in smart city networks, smart homes, and internet access in remote regions. The technology is looking for industrial partners to bring Li-Fi routers to a more mainstream audience.

One of the first of its kind, Dash is a robot measuring around 90cm design to move at walking pace and capable of carrying small amounts of goods up to rooms so a human doesn't have to.

In a way, Dash kind of looks like a robotic garbage bin, except it carries things you'll want — not garbage — and is WiFi controlled, moving along the ground by itself and even able to call for an elevator, relying on a link to the hotel to find out where it should be delivering items to.

Dash is one of the first times we've seen a robot arrive in the hospitality space, working in a real-life environment and guests, who will be able to order things and then interact with the robot as it arrives outside their door, before sending itself on its merry way before it returns to the front desk and recharges itself.

Checking with Crowne's people, we were told that Australia might see the robot in the future, but it wouldn't be immediately, advising "should testing be successful, it's not impossible for Dash to be rolled out down under".

text.Prompt:
National Australia Bank's defence to similar claims of market manipulation and unconscionable conduct is due to be filed in October.

Unconscionable conduct

But the wording of parts of the NAB statement of claim, which was filed two months after the case against Westpac and three months after the case against ANZ, provided more scope for ASIC to make out its claim of unconscionable conduct, according to legal sources.

The filing of ASIC's newly drafted claims against Westpac and ANZ may coincide with the regulator launching a similar case against Commonwealth Bank of Australia, the only one of the big four banks not to have been sued over the allegations in the Federal Court.

ASIC refused to comment on the timing of any case against CBA. The bank is expecting a claim will be filed later this week.

It is understood CBA has no interest in settling with the regulator so long as it is required to provide an admission of unconscionable conduct. All of the banks are concerned such as admission will expose them to damages claims through class actions, after plaintiff law firm Maurice Blackburn said last month it is investigating such actions.

Advertisement

The Federal Court has set a provisional trial date for the cases of August 1 next year.

Tried together

In a case management hearing last month, Federal Court judge Jonathan Beach pushed back on ASIC's request for the case against ANZ to be heard first, which could have created a legal precedent to put pressure on the other banks to settle.

Rather, Justice Beach said his "provisional view" is that the three cases be tried together. He wants all the common issues vented at the first stage, and then to hear all the ANZ-specific issues, then the Westpac-specific issues and then the NAB-specific issues.

"I accept that in terms of the detail of some of the allegations and transactions there is still more to be disclosed by ASIC and to be looked at by each of the three banks, but it seems to be in relation to the matters of principle that I think all parties should have a fairly reasonable idea of what those issues of principle are at the moment," the judge said.

Another case management hearing is due to be held on August 22.

Generate a summary:
text.Response A: The Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) has launched a lawsuit against the Commonwealth Bank of Australia (CBA) over claims the bank illegally manipulated the Bank Bill Swap Rate (BBSW), a key interest rate used for the pricing of financial instruments and derivatives. ASIC's lawsuit is similar to those filed against ANZ Bank, Westpac and National Australia Bank (NAB) in 2017 and 2018 regarding alleged market manipulation and unconscionable conduct. The action follows a recent ruling in the New South Wales Supreme Court that found CBA engaged in unconscionable conduct in its dealings with small business customers. The Federal Court has set a provisional trial date for the cases of August 1 next year.
text.Response B: ASIC is filing new claims against Westpac and ANZ, alleging unconscionable conduct. The regulator refused to comment on the timing of any case against CBA. All banks are concerned about an admission of unconscionable conduct as it would expose them to damages claims. The Federal Court has set a provisional trial date for the cases of August 1 next year.

KUALA LUMPUR (May 4): Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd's (ANZ) chief hinted that 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB) concerns had an indirect impact on ANZ's stake in AMMB Holdings Bhd, The Australian reported today.

AMMB is also known as AmBank.

The Australian quoted ANZ chief executive Shayne Elliott as saying it was unquestionable that 1MDB' debt concerns and the Malaysian economy had a broad-base impact on Malaysian asset valuations. AMMB's share price was no exception, according to him.

"Has the 1MDB and the Malaysian economy and all those situations, impacted the AmBank share price? Unquestionably."

"It's impacted the valuation of lots of things in Malaysia, so it will have had an impact. But it's not a direct response to that," Elliott was quoted as saying in a press conference yesterday (May 3), during the announcement of ANZ's first-half financials.

ANZ via ANZ Funds Pty Ltd is the largest shareholder in AMMB, with a 23.78% stake.

At Bursa Malaysia today, AMMB shares rose eight sen or 1.8% at 12:30pm to RM4.56 for a market value of RM13.72 billion.

AMMB's current share price compares with the stock's one-year intraday high at RM6.21 seen on May 5, 2015.

In Australia yesterday, Elliott said there was "no 1MDB issue" for the ANZ board to discuss.

"We don't have an exposure to 1MDB. In terms of our partnership or the minority investment that we have in (AmBank's holding company) AMMB, all of those stakes get discussed regularly," he said.

Yesterday, ANZ said it incurred a A$260 million (about RM1.03 billion) impairment for its investment in AMMB during the first half ended March 31, 2016 (1HFY16).

ANZ told the Australian bourse that the AMMB impairment was among reasons for ANZ's weaker 1HFY16 financials, compared to a year earlier. During 1HFY16, ANZ said statutory profit after tax fell to A$2.74 billion, from A$3.51 billion.

At the press conference, Elliott said ANZ had cut its investment value in AMMB by almost 20% or A$260 million.

The Australian reported that "ANZ chief financial officer Graeme Hodges refused to say how much money AmBank had on loan to 1MDB."

text.Prompt:
The operator of the crippled Fukushima nuclear plant said it has removed a 20-ton piece of rubble from a destroyed reactor in what it called a "major step forward" in decommissioning.

After months of planning, Tokyo Electric Power Co (Tepco) said it used giant cranes on Sunday to lift one fuel handling machine, which was destroyed when a quake-sparked tsunami sent some of the plant's reactors into meltdown in March 2011.

The company described the delicate operation as a critical step toward clearing highly radioactive spent fuel rods from the cooling pool inside its badly damaged Reactor number 3.

The fuel handling machine was a key part of the process that transferred nuclear fuel assemblies into the reactor core.

"It paves the way for continued progress and is a milestone in reducing the risk of removing spent fuel assemblies," said the company's chief decommissioning officer Naohiro Masuda.

Removing fuel from the pool at the site's reactors is scheduled to last until the second half of 2021.

However, decommissioning efforts to clean up the debris at the shattered plant are expected to last some four decades.

The announcement comes several days after the government said compensation costs from the worst nuclear disaster since Chernobyl in 1986 are expected to be more than $57 billion.

Tokyo has poured billions of dollars into the embattled company to keep it afloat as it stumps up cash for decommissioning the reactors, cleaning up the mess from the disaster and paying compensation.

text.Response A:
Sure! Here's a recipe for making fondant cherry blossoms:

Ingredients:

- 1/4 cup (60 g) granulated sugar
- 1/4 cup (60 g) powdered sugar
- 1/2 teaspoon (2 g) vanilla extract
- 1/4 teaspoon (1 g) almond extract
- 1/4 teaspoon (1 g) salt
- 1/4 teaspoon (1 g) red food coloring
- 1/4 teaspoon (1 g) yellow food coloring
- 1/4 teaspoon (1 g) pink food coloring
- 1/4 teaspoon (1 g) green food coloring
- 1/4 teaspoon (1 g) orange food coloring
- 1/4 teaspoon (1 g) purple food coloring
- 1/4 teaspoon (1 g) blue food coloring
- 1/4 teaspoon (1 g) black food coloring
- 1/4 teaspoon (1 g) white food coloring
- 1/4 teaspoon (1 g) red food coloring
- 1/4 teaspoon (1 g) yellow food coloring
- 1/4 teaspoon (1 g) pink food coloring
- 1/4 teaspoon (1 g) green food coloring
- 1/4 teaspoon (1 g) orange food coloring
- 1/4 teaspoon (1 g) purple food coloring
- 1/4 teaspoon (1 g) blue food coloring
- 1/4 teaspoon (1 g) black food coloring
- 1/4 teaspoon (1 g) white food coloring

Directions:

1. In a large bowl, combine the granulated sugar, powdered sugar, vanilla extract, almond extract, salt, red food coloring, yellow food coloring, pink food coloring, green food coloring, orange food coloring, purple food coloring, blue food coloring, black food coloring, and white food coloring.
2. Mix well until the color is evenly distributed.
3. Add the fondant cherry blossoms to the bowl and mix well until the fondant cherry blossoms are evenly distributed.
4. Store the fondant cherry blossoms in an airtight container for up to a week.

The Li-Fi prototype relies on solar energy to power Internet connections so that an LED light source paired with a solar panel becomes a fully functional transmitter and receiver system for high speed, secure data transfer. Instead of relying on hardwired cables or radio waves that are easily interrupted, Li-Fi uses the nearly undetectable flicker of an LED light to transmit data.

Li-Fi is much faster than most standard Wi-Fi connections, and, perhaps most importantly, provides a connection that is significantly more secure. Because Li-Fi relies on light to transmit data, you have to be in the room with your device and the Li-Fi router in order to get connected. That would preclude strangers or literal outsiders from piggy-backing on your connection or eavesdropping on your online activity.

Beyond the widespread Internet access that Li-Fi could help provide around the world, the technology also has applications for reliable systems like smart city networks and Internet of Things connectivity in the smart homes of the future.

"The wider opportunity is to transform global communications by speeding up the process of bringing Internet and other data communication functionality to remote and poorer regions in a way not previously thought achievable due to lack of infrastructure and investment," said Tom Higgison, Edinburgh Research & Innovation's IP Project Manager. Edinburgh Research & Innovation is the commercial branch of the technological developments accomplished on the University side, and they have announced they are looking for industrial partners to help bring Li-Fi routers to a more mainstream audience.

Editors' Recommendations

The operator of the crippled Fukushima nuclear plant said it has removed a 20-ton piece of rubble from a destroyed reactor in what it called a "major step forward" in decommissioning.

After months of planning, Tokyo Electric Power Co (Tepco) said it used giant cranes on Sunday to lift one fuel handling machine, which was destroyed when a quake-sparked tsunami sent some of the plant's reactors into meltdown in March 2011.

The company described the delicate operation as a critical step toward clearing highly radioactive spent fuel rods from the cooling pool inside its badly damaged Reactor number 3.

The fuel handling machine was a key part of the process that transferred nuclear fuel assemblies into the reactor core.

"It paves the way for continued progress and is a milestone in reducing the risk of removing spent fuel assemblies," said the company's chief decommissioning officer Naohiro Masuda.

Removing fuel from the pool at the site's reactors is scheduled to last until the second half of 2021.

However, decommissioning efforts to clean up the debris at the shattered plant are expected to last some four decades.

The announcement comes several days after the government said compensation costs from the worst nuclear disaster since Chernobyl in 1986 are expected to be more than $57 billion.

Tokyo has poured billions of dollars into the embattled company to keep it afloat as it stumps up cash for decommissioning the reactors, cleaning up the mess from the disaster and paying compensation.

text.Prompt:
Through a collaboration between the University of Edinburgh's Li-FI R&D Centre and a university offshoot company called pureLiFi Ltd, the past four years have brought light-powered Internet connectivity out of the theoretical stage and into a tangible Li-Fi router. The real-world applications for Li-Fi connectivity could revolutionize the way much of the world gets online. The R&D team bringing Li-Fi to the real world expects that solar homes, consumer gadgets, and Internet of things devices will all be able to absorb power and receive data simultaneously with a Li-Fi system in place.

The Li-Fi prototype relies on solar energy to power Internet connections so that an LED light source paired with a solar panel becomes a fully functional transmitter and receiver system for high speed, secure data transfer. Instead of relying on hardwired cables or radio waves that are easily interrupted, Li-Fi uses the nearly undetectable flicker of an LED light to transmit data.

Li-Fi is much faster than most standard Wi-Fi connections, and, perhaps most importantly, provides a connection that is significantly more secure. Because Li-Fi relies on light to transmit data, you have to be in the room with your device and the Li-Fi router in order to get connected. That would preclude strangers or literal outsiders from piggy-backing on your connection or eavesdropping on your online activity.

Beyond the widespread Internet access that Li-Fi could help provide around the world, the technology also has applications for reliable systems like smart city networks and Internet of Things connectivity in the smart homes of the future.

"The wider opportunity is to transform global communications by speeding up the process of bringing Internet and other data communication functionality to remote and poorer regions in a way not previously thought achievable due to lack of infrastructure and investment," said Tom Higgison, Edinburgh Research & Innovation's IP Project Manager. Edinburgh Research & Innovation is the commercial branch of the technological developments accomplished on the University side, and they have announced they are looking for industrial partners to help bring Li-Fi routers to a more mainstream audience.

Editors' Recommendations

text.Prompt: Can you tell me how to make wicked the musical cupcakes?
text.Response A:
Sure! Here's a recipe for Wicked the Musical cupcakes:

Ingredients:
1 cup all-purpose flour
1 cup sugar
3 tablespoons cocoa powder
1 teaspoon baking soda
1 teaspoon baking powder
1/2 teaspoon salt
2 cups milk
1/2 cup vegetable oil
2 eggs
1 teaspoon vanilla extract

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Line a muffin tin with paper muffin cups.
2. In a large bowl, combine flour, sugar, cocoa powder, baking soda, baking powder, and salt. In a separate bowl, whisk together milk, oil, eggs, and vanilla extract.
3. Add wet ingredients to dry ingredients and stir until just combined.
4. Fill muffin cups 2/3 full with batter.
5. Bake for 20-25 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted into the center of a cupcake comes out clean.
6. Let cupcakes cool in tin for 5 minutes, then remove to a wire rack to cool completely.
7. To make the frosting, combine 1/2 cup butter, 1/2 cup sugar, and 1/2 cup cocoa powder in a bowl. Beat until smooth. Add 1/2 cup milk and 1 teaspoon vanilla extract and beat until combined.
8. Frost cupcakes and enjoy!

Next you can follow this video tutorial from the Cupcake Collective to create the beautiful flower cupcake toppers: https://youtu.be/kUv1VQk2QjA. The hardest part is getting the fondant to stick to the cupcake, but as long as you use enough buttercream as “glue”, it should work out well. Finally, I recommend ordering these edible glitter sheets to add some sparkle to the beautiful roses you’ll create: https://amzn.to/3lz0h9u. Now, embattled Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro announced on Sunday that the 100-bolivar bill will be decommissioned.

On Sunday, President Maduro seems to have taken a page out of Modi's book, referring to "mafias" smuggling the currency.

President Nicolas Maduro said on state television:

"There has been a scam and smuggling of the one hundred bills on the border with Colombia. We have tried the diplomatic way to deal with this problem with Colombia's government; there are huge mafias. I have decided to take out of circulation bills of 100 bolivars in the next 72 hours. We must keep beating the mafias."

Venezuela is in the middle of a vicious case of hyper-inflation that has seen the rate for their bolivar versus the world's global reserve currency, and the U.S. dollar, fall over 50 percent in the black market within the past month. Many are asked to use bank transfers instead of cash or even card payments.

Venezuela is on a growing list of nations with national currency devaluations. The list includes China, which has seen six national devaluations in the last twelve months, Zimbabwe, Brazil, Argentina, Spain, Italy, Great Britain and Ukraine. Every weakening of a nation currency, or a cash ban by a national banking system, seems to strengthen the global demand and value for Bitcoin.

text.Prompt: Can you tell me how to get your cat out of the malnutrition stage?
text.Response A: Cats can be really tricky when it comes to their diets, and they can get into some unhealthy patterns if you’re not careful.  If you think your cat is malnourished, or “underweight”, it’s important to take the right steps to help your cat.  One thing that’s really important is to reduce stress in your cat’s life, and make sure your cat is getting enough good quality food.  A healthy, happy cat is a cat that’s less likely to develop an eating disorder.  You can also try a special cat food that’s designed for cats that are underweight, and there are also a number of cat supplements you can add to your cat’s food to help it gain weight.  There are also veterinarians who can help you with this.
text.Response B:
I'm sorry to hear that your cat is experiencing malnutrition. It's important to remember that cats are obligate carnivores, meaning that they require a diet that is rich in animal protein in order to meet their nutritional needs.

If your cat is experiencing malnutrition, the first step is to seek the advice of a veterinarian. Your veterinarian will be able to assess your cat's condition and provide appropriate treatment. This may include a diet change, supplements, and other interventions to help your cat recover.

In the meantime, it's important to feed your cat a balanced and nutritious diet that meets their nutritional needs. This may involve feeding your cat a commercial cat food that is designed to provide the necessary nutrients, or preparing your own cat food at home using high-quality ingredients.

It's also important to ensure that your cat is getting enough exercise and activity. Cats are active creatures and need regular opportunities to exercise and play in order to stay healthy.

If you're concerned about your cat's weight or overall health, it's important to consult with a veterinarian as soon as possible. Your veterinarian will be able to provide you with guidance and support to help your cat recover and maintain a healthy weight.

text.Prompt: Can you tell me how to form an llc in illinois?
text.Response A:
Sure, I can help you with that! Here are the general steps you'll need to take to form an LLC in Illinois:

1. Choose a business name: You'll need to choose a unique and distinguishable name for your LLC. You can search for existing businesses in Illinois to make sure your chosen name isn't already being used by another company.

2. Choose a registered agent: You'll need to appoint a registered agent to receive legal documents on behalf of your LLC. The registered agent can be an individual or a business, and they must be located in Illinois.

3. File the articles of organization: You'll need to file the articles of organization with the Illinois Secretary of State's office to officially form your LLC. This document will include information about your LLC, such as its name, registered agent, and purpose.

4. Obtain an employer identification number (EIN): You'll need to obtain an EIN from the IRS to identify your LLC for tax purposes. You can apply for an EIN online or by mail.

5. Register for taxes: You'll need to register your LLC for taxes with the Illinois Department of Revenue. This will typically involve filing an Illinois Business Tax Return (IBT).

6. Obtain licenses and permits: You may need to obtain additional licenses and permits depending on the type of business you're operating. For example, if you're a restaurant, you may need a food service permit.

7. Maintain records: You'll need to keep records of your LLC's activities, including financial records and minutes of meetings. These records will be helpful if you ever need to file taxes or deal with legal issues.

8. Provide information to the public: You'll need to provide information about your LLC to the public, such as its name, registered agent, and purpose. You can do this by filing a notice of organization with the Illinois Secretary of State's office.

I hope this helps! If you have any specific questions about forming an LLC in Illinois, feel free to ask me.

Sure!  Fish cakes are a common appetizer or side dish in many Asian cuisines, and are made from ground fish mixed with various flavorings and seasonings, then formed into small patties or cakes.  The cakes can then be fried or baked until cooked through, and are usually served with a dipping sauce.  There are many different variations of fish cakes, using different types of fish and various seasonings and flavorings, but a basic recipe might call for:

1 lb ground fish (any firm white fish such as pollock, hake, or cod can be used)
1 tsp grated fresh ginger
1 clove garlic, minced
1 tbsp soy sauce
1 tbsp rice wine or white vinegar
1 tbsp sesame oil
2 tsp chili garlic sauce (or other spicy chili sauce)
1 tbsp sesame seeds

Place the fish in a bowl and break up any large chunks with a fork.  Add the ginger, garlic, soy sauce, vinegar, sesame oil, and chili garlic sauce, and mix well to combine. "We see a huge interest in Bitcoin as an asset class. So, we have launched the product for the German/Austrian market, too. Germany is one of the biggest and most sophisticated structured products markets and it is one of Vontobel's focus markets."

The certificate is a simple bankable asset that is particularly suitable for investors who anticipate a rise in the acceptance and significance of Bitcoin as a way of payment and as an alternative currency.

Vontobel, which manages and monitors a client's assets entrusted to it and also observes the financial markets and interprets global macroeconomic developments, is the first Swiss issuer of a tracker certificate on Bitcoins for subscription.

Switzerland has been dubbed a conducive environment for Bitcoin to thrive, due to its regulatory friendly measures for the digital currency.

Good regulations

With the launch of this tracker certificate in Germany, Geiger says the environment could also be considered encouraging for similar investments.

"The fact that we have launched the product and are able to do a public offer shows that the regulatory environment in Germany also suits these kind of investments."

Before the launch in Switzerland, the bank maintained that the impact of the product on the price of Bitcoin "will most likely be very low." Trading commenced earlier this year on July 15, with Bitcoins purchased according to the subscriptions received from clients on that day, and with the products to be redeemed on July 23, 2018.

Depending on the market environment and the client interest, they will possibly issue a new product afterwards.

Vontobel's reputation spreads across 22 international locations where they identify and analyze trends, and subsequently create innovative investment strategies and products for investors.

1. Lack of preparation:
Not preparing enough can lead to a lack of confidence and clarity.

Using technical terms or jargon can confuse or alienate the audience.

Public speaking is not about you; it's about your message and how it can benefit your audience.

Speaking too fast or too slow can be distracting and make it difficult for the audience to follow your message.

National Australia Bank's defence to similar claims of market manipulation and unconscionable conduct is due to be filed in October.

Unconscionable conduct

But the wording of parts of the NAB statement of claim, which was filed two months after the case against Westpac and three months after the case against ANZ, provided more scope for ASIC to make out its claim of unconscionable conduct, according to legal sources.

The filing of ASIC's newly drafted claims against Westpac and ANZ may coincide with the regulator launching a similar case against Commonwealth Bank of Australia, the only one of the big four banks not to have been sued over the allegations in the Federal Court.

ASIC refused to comment on the timing of any case against CBA. The bank is expecting a claim will be filed later this week.

It is understood CBA has no interest in settling with the regulator so long as it is required to provide an admission of unconscionable conduct. All of the banks are concerned such as admission will expose them to damages claims through class actions, after plaintiff law firm Maurice Blackburn said last month it is investigating such actions.

Advertisement

The Federal Court has set a provisional trial date for the cases of August 1 next year.

Tried together

In a case management hearing last month, Federal Court judge Jonathan Beach pushed back on ASIC's request for the case against ANZ to be heard first, which could have created a legal precedent to put pressure on the other banks to settle.

Rather, Justice Beach said his "provisional view" is that the three cases be tried together. He wants all the common issues vented at the first stage, and then to hear all the ANZ-specific issues, then the Westpac-specific issues and then the NAB-specific issues.

"I accept that in terms of the detail of some of the allegations and transactions there is still more to be disclosed by ASIC and to be looked at by each of the three banks, but it seems to be in relation to the matters of principle that I think all parties should have a fairly reasonable idea of what those issues of principle are at the moment," the judge said.

Another case management hearing is due to be held on August 22.
