text.Prompt:
The skies over America are set to get a lot noisier this holiday season with around a million new quadcopters expected to be unwrapped at the end of the year.

The prospect of so many untrained hobbyists send their remotely controlled machines skyward is causing some serious concern at the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA), which so far this year has had to deal with reports of hundreds of near misses between manned planes and drones.

With the technology gaining more exposure, and costs coming down, it's a dead cert the flying machines will be one of the most popular gifts this coming holiday season. And while the vast majority of people are sensible enough to consult their gray matter when it comes to working out the safest way – and place – to have fun with their copter, there's always a few bozos ready to spoil the party.

Voicing concern during the Airlines for America Commercial Aviation Industry Summit in DC this week, FAA official Rich Swayze said the agency was "trying to get out and educate people about potential dangers" of drones ahead of the holiday season, Aviation Week reported. "A lot of people who don't have a pilot background are operating these things in the airspace," Swayze said.

FAA action includes advising Walmart sales personnel on key safety points to pass on to consumers to ensure proper operation of the unmanned aerial vehicles. The retail giant currently offers dozens of drones or similar machines, some for as little as $20.

Also speaking at the conference, Hawaiian Airlines CEO Mark Dunkerley called quadcopters "a very serious issue," adding, "There's considerable concern that it's going to end in tears."

Know Before You Fly

Hoping to grab the attention of new hobbyist drone operators last Christmas, the FAA launched its "Know Before You Fly" video (above) on how to enjoy the machines without the worry of having it crash onto someone's head or, in a worst case scenario, bringing down a much bigger aircraft.

Safe operation includes keeping your flying machine below 400 feet and within sight at all times, and well away from airports and crowds. The FAA also recommends joining a flying club if there's one nearby, and to always inspect your aircraft before take-off. Happy flying!

Editors' Recommendations

5. Bake the circles in a preheated oven at 200 degrees Fahrenheit for about 15 minutes, or until they are firm and dry.
6. Once the circles are cool, use a small paintbrush to apply a thin layer of edible glue to the back of each one.
7. Stick the circles together in a cluster, with the glue holding them in place.
8. Use a toothpick to make a small hole in the center of the cluster.

AMMB is also known as AmBank.

The Australian quoted ANZ chief executive Shayne Elliott as saying it was unquestionable that 1MDB' debt concerns and the Malaysian economy had a broad-base impact on Malaysian asset valuations. AMMB's share price was no exception, according to him.

"Has the 1MDB and the Malaysian economy and all those situations, impacted the AmBank share price? Unquestionably."

"It's impacted the valuation of lots of things in Malaysia, so it will have had an impact. But it's not a direct response to that," Elliott was quoted as saying in a press conference yesterday (May 3), during the announcement of ANZ's first-half financials.

ANZ via ANZ Funds Pty Ltd is the largest shareholder in AMMB, with a 23.78% stake.

At Bursa Malaysia today, AMMB shares rose eight sen or 1.8% at 12:30pm to RM4.56 for a market value of RM13.72 billion.

AMMB's current share price compares with the stock's one-year intraday high at RM6.21 seen on May 5, 2015.

In Australia yesterday, Elliott said there was "no 1MDB issue" for the ANZ board to discuss.

"We don't have an exposure to 1MDB. In terms of our partnership or the minority investment that we have in (AmBank's holding company) AMMB, all of those stakes get discussed regularly," he said.

Yesterday, ANZ said it incurred a A$260 million (about RM1.03 billion) impairment for its investment in AMMB during the first half ended March 31, 2016 (1HFY16).

ANZ told the Australian bourse that the AMMB impairment was among reasons for ANZ's weaker 1HFY16 financials, compared to a year earlier. During 1HFY16, ANZ said statutory profit after tax fell to A$2.74 billion, from A$3.51 billion.

At the press conference, Elliott said ANZ had cut its investment value in AMMB by almost 20% or A$260 million.

The Australian reported that "ANZ chief financial officer Graeme Hodges refused to say how much money AmBank had on loan to 1MDB."

According to THEnergy, until very recently, there was little activity among mining companies regarding renewable energy. A recent report from CDP, formerly known as the Carbon Disclosure Project, concluded that the biggest miners are "unprepared for the transition to a low-carbon economy". 11 large mining companies were analysed and 9 opposed new climate regulations and only two stated support for "climate regulation." Perhaps this is due to the fact that for many mining companies, the main threat lies in new charges on coal.

Following this, THEnergy has realised that many of the large mining companies have started to focus on short-term actions regarding powering their mines: they have been preparing actions plans to react to carbon-reduction measures that might be adopted at the Paris climate conference. Large mining companies are also working on a strategy for renewable-energy projects such as wind and solar power at their mines. Companies like Rio Tinto, Glencore, BHP Billiton and Goldfields have already finished their first pilot power plants or have recently announced new projects.

Energy typically amounts to approximately 20–30% of the operating costs of a mine as such strict carbon-reduction decisions at the Paris climate conference could have a strong influence on the cost position of mines. As renewable energy can be less expensive than electricity from conventional energy sources, THEnergy stated, mining companies that manage to adapt early to the challenges of a low-carbon economy could gain significant competitive advantages.

"Mining companies are in the process of understanding that renewable energy can largely improve their competitive situation. Many miners struggle, however, to make the necessary decisions quickly as they face severe market challenges from falling commodity prices at the same time," explained Dr. Thomas Hillig, CEO of the consulting firm THEnergy, which specialises in the topic of renewables and mining. "We are in a normal learning process, many mining companies have already understood that the prices of solar and wind power have decreased considerably in the last years. If significant carbon reduction measures are adopted at the Paris climate conference, we will see many solar and wind plants at mines in the very near future."

Edited from press release by Angharad Lock

"If significant carbon reduction measures are adopted at the Paris climate conference, we will see many solar and wind plants at mines in the very near future," said Dr. Thomas Hillig, CEO of the consulting firm THEnergy.

However, there are challenges such as falling commodity prices and increased competition that miners need to overcome in order to make the necessary changes. The author is confident that miners will overcome these challenges and implement renewable energy projects at their mines in the near future.

text.Prompt: Can you tell me how to make albondigas meatballs?
text.Response A:
Sure! Here is a simple recipe for making albondigas meatballs:

Ingredients:
- 1 pound ground beef
- 1/4 cup dry breadcrumbs
- 1/4 cup finely grated Parmesan cheese
- 1/4 cup chopped fresh parsley
- 1/4 cup chopped onion
- 1/4 cup chopped green bell pepper
- 2 cloves garlic, minced
- 1 egg
- 1/2 teaspoon ground black pepper
- 1/2 teaspoon ground cumin
- 1/4 teaspoon ground cinnamon
- 1/4 teaspoon salt
- 2 cups beef broth
- 1 cup dry white wine
- 2 tablespoons chopped fresh cilantro
- 1 tablespoon lime juice

Directions:
1. Preheat the oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
2. In a large bowl, mix together the ground beef, bread crumbs, Parmesan cheese, parsley, onion, green pepper, garlic, egg, black pepper, cumin, cinnamon, and salt. Shape into 1 inch balls.
3. Arrange the meatballs in a single layer in a baking dish. Bake in the preheated oven for 25 minutes.
4. In a large saucepan, combine the beef broth, white wine, cilantro, and lime juice. Bring to a boil over medium heat.
5. Reduce heat to low, and stir in the meatballs. Simmer for 10 minutes.

Enjoy!

Ooh yay! Me want tell you how make yummiest albondigas meatballs!

First, get mama's big bowl. Put in big ol' spoon of flour, then egg, then porky meat (not too much, mama!). Mixy mixy till all same-y.

Next, get spicy spicy salt and pepper. Sprinkle sprinkle on meat mix. Mama like!

Now, get big ol' fork and make little meatballs. Mama like bite-y size. Make lotsa little meatballs!

In big ol' pan, put oil. When oil hot, put in meatballs. Cooky cooky till brown-y.

When done, get mama's yummiest sauce. Pour pour on meatballs. Mama like!

Meatballs ready! Mama eat now! Yum yum yum!

"Has the 1MDB and the Malaysian economy and all those situations, impacted the AmBank share price? Unquestionably."

"It's impacted the valuation of lots of things in Malaysia, so it will have had an impact. But it's not a direct response to that," Elliott was quoted as saying in a press conference yesterday (May 3), during the announcement of ANZ's first-half financials.

ANZ via ANZ Funds Pty Ltd is the largest shareholder in AMMB, with a 23.78% stake.

At Bursa Malaysia today, AMMB shares rose eight sen or 1.8% at 12:30pm to RM4.56 for a market value of RM13.72 billion.

AMMB's current share price compares with the stock's one-year intraday high at RM6.21 seen on May 5, 2015.

In Australia yesterday, Elliott said there was "no 1MDB issue" for the ANZ board to discuss.

"We don't have an exposure to 1MDB. In terms of our partnership or the minority investment that we have in (AmBank's holding company) AMMB, all of those stakes get discussed regularly," he said.

ANZ told the Australian bourse that the AMMB impairment was among reasons for ANZ's weaker 1HFY16 financials, compared to a year earlier. During 1HFY16, ANZ said statutory profit after tax fell to A$2.74 billion, from A$3.51 billion.

China will also lead an international research group on the standardization of the Internet of Things (IoT) and blockchain technology, as Cointelegraph reported July 18.

China has also recently downplayed blockchain tech, as the head of the international department of the China Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission warned against "mythologizing" blockchain technology in mid-July.

It will enable new business models and use cases, and promote financial innovation.  However, the report emphasizes that it is necessary to differentiate between the "coin" application and the "chain" application of blockchain technology, and that financial risks should be strictly guarded.

It will be interesting to see how blockchain technology is adopted and regulated in China, and how it evolves globally in the financial services industry.

text.Response A:
Dog DNA testing and parentage analysis are important tools for breeders and dog owners who want to learn more about their dogs' genetic makeup and ancestry. There are several ways to test dog DNA and analyze parentage, including DNA sequencing, DNA microarrays, and DNA genotyping.

One of the most common methods for dog DNA testing and parentage analysis is DNA sequencing. This method involves sequencing the DNA of the dog in question and comparing it to the DNA of other dogs to determine similarities and differences. This can help to identify genetic mutations and variations that may be relevant to the dog's health and well-being.

Another method for dog DNA testing and parentage analysis is DNA microarrays. This method involves using a microarray to compare the DNA of the dog in question to the DNA of other dogs. This can help to identify genetic variations and mutations that may be relevant to the dog's health and well-being.

Finally, DNA genotyping is another method for dog DNA testing and parentage analysis. This method involves using DNA genotyping to compare the DNA of the dog in question to the DNA of other dogs. This can help to identify genetic variations and mutations that may be relevant to the dog's health and well-being.

No matter which method you choose for dog DNA testing and parentage analysis, it is important to consider the accuracy and reliability of the results. It is also important to consider the cost and convenience of the test, as well as the potential benefits and risks of the test.

text.Prompt: Can you tell me how to clean a hot tub?
text.Response A:
Of course, I'd be happy to help! Cleaning a hot tub requires some regular maintenance to keep it in good condition and ensure the water is safe for use. Here's a step-by-step guide on how to clean a hot tub:

1. Test the water: Before you start cleaning, it's essential to test the water to ensure it's safe for use. Use a hot tub test strips or a pH test kit to check the water's pH level, alkalinity, and calcium hardness.
2. Remove any debris: Start by removing any visible debris, such as leaves or twigs, from the hot tub using a skimmer or a leaf rake.
3. Clean the hot tub cover: The cover of your hot tub can accumulate dirt, algae, and other contaminants over time. Use a mild detergent and a soft-bristled brush to clean the cover. Avoid using harsh chemicals or abrasive materials that can damage the cover.
4. Clean the hot tub shell: Use a soft-bristled brush to scrub the hot tub shell, paying particular attention to any areas with visible algae or dirt buildup.
5. Clean the jets and return fittings: Use a brush or a small scrubber to clean the jets and return fittings. Make sure to remove any algae or dirt that may be clogging them.
6. Vacuum the hot tub: Use a hot tub vacuum to remove any debris or sediment from the bottom of the hot tub.
7. Shock the water: Shocking the water is an essential step in cleaning your hot tub. It helps to kill any bacteria or algae that may be present in the water. Use a non-chlorine shock treatment, and follow the manufacturer's instructions for proper dosing.
8. Balance the water: After shocking the water, you'll need to balance the pH level, alkalinity, and calcium hardness to ensure the water is safe for use. Use a hot tub test kit to check the water's balance, and adjust as needed.
9. Filter the water: Run the hot tub's filter for at least 24 hours
text.Response B: Yes, cleaning a hot tub is very important to keep the water clean and safe for use.  The first step is to skim the surface of the water with a net to remove any leaves, dirt, or other debris.  Next, add a hot tub cleaning solution to the water and let it sit for several minutes.  Then use a long-handled brush to scrub the sides and bottom of the tub, and a pool skimmer to remove any debris from the water.  Finally, rinse the tub with a hose to remove all cleaning solution, and replace the water with fresh, clean water.

text.Prompt:
KUALA LUMPUR (May 4): Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd's (ANZ) chief hinted that 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB) concerns had an indirect impact on ANZ's stake in AMMB Holdings Bhd, The Australian reported today.

AMMB is also known as AmBank.

The Australian quoted ANZ chief executive Shayne Elliott as saying it was unquestionable that 1MDB' debt concerns and the Malaysian economy had a broad-base impact on Malaysian asset valuations. AMMB's share price was no exception, according to him.

"Has the 1MDB and the Malaysian economy and all those situations, impacted the AmBank share price? Unquestionably."

"It's impacted the valuation of lots of things in Malaysia, so it will have had an impact. But it's not a direct response to that," Elliott was quoted as saying in a press conference yesterday (May 3), during the announcement of ANZ's first-half financials.

ANZ via ANZ Funds Pty Ltd is the largest shareholder in AMMB, with a 23.78% stake.

At Bursa Malaysia today, AMMB shares rose eight sen or 1.8% at 12:30pm to RM4.56 for a market value of RM13.72 billion.

AMMB's current share price compares with the stock's one-year intraday high at RM6.21 seen on May 5, 2015.

In Australia yesterday, Elliott said there was "no 1MDB issue" for the ANZ board to discuss.

"We don't have an exposure to 1MDB. In terms of our partnership or the minority investment that we have in (AmBank's holding company) AMMB, all of those stakes get discussed regularly," he said.

Yesterday, ANZ said it incurred a A$260 million (about RM1.03 billion) impairment for its investment in AMMB during the first half ended March 31, 2016 (1HFY16).

ANZ told the Australian bourse that the AMMB impairment was among reasons for ANZ's weaker 1HFY16 financials, compared to a year earlier. During 1HFY16, ANZ said statutory profit after tax fell to A$2.74 billion, from A$3.51 billion.

At the press conference, Elliott said ANZ had cut its investment value in AMMB by almost 20% or A$260 million.

The Australian reported that "ANZ chief financial officer Graeme Hodges refused to say how much money AmBank had on loan to 1MDB."

text.Prompt: Can you tell me how to test dog dna and analyze parentage?
text.Response A:
There are several ways to test dog DNA and analyze parentage. One way is to use a DNA testing kit, which can be purchased online or at some pet stores. These kits typically include a swab that you can use to collect a sample of your dog's DNA. You then send the sample back to the company for analysis.

Another way to test dog DNA and analyze parentage is to use a service provided by a veterinarian or animal hospital. They will typically collect a blood sample from your dog and send it to a laboratory for analysis.

It's important to note that the accuracy of dog DNA tests can vary, so it's always a good idea to consult with a veterinarian or animal geneticist to get the most accurate results.

There are a few ways to test dog DNA and analyze parentage. One way is to use a DNA testing kit, which you can purchase online or at some pet stores. These kits typically involve collecting a sample of your dog's saliva or blood and sending it to a laboratory for analysis. The laboratory will then use genetic testing to determine your dog's DNA profile and compare it to other dogs' DNA profiles to determine its parentage.

Another way to test dog DNA and analyze parentage is to take your dog to a veterinarian or animal geneticist who can perform a DNA test on your dog. This is typically a more expensive option, but it may be necessary if you are trying to determine the parentage of a specific dog or if you are interested in genetic testing for your dog.

It's important to note that DNA testing can be a helpful tool for determining parentage, but it is not always accurate. There are many factors that can affect the accuracy of DNA testing, including the quality of the sample, the method of analysis, and the expertise of the laboratory or veterinarian performing the test. It's always a good idea to speak with a veterinarian or animal geneticist before having a DNA test performed on your dog to discuss the potential risks and benefits.
